title: A formerly great company changing direction
pros: Great, hard working people working in Weyerhaeuser facilities who really care about each other, have deep roots in the forest products industry, and are very committed to meet the needs of their customers. Safety is serious value and is imbedded in everything.
cons: An over 100 year old company which was built on creating sustainable growth and results for your grandchildren's generation has now evolved to caring only about the short term results to the shareholder. The company has progressed from 55,000 employees (with too much bureaucracy) to a 13,000 person company with no soul. Too leaders are only good at figuring out how to sell off everything for cash vs the ability to make those businesses successful. The engagement of employees has been slowly eroding in the last 5-10 years with senior leadership continually demonstrating their lack of respect and regard for the people who have built and sustained this formerly great company. Most employees were initially excited about the energy of the new CEO, but after a year it appears he is driven by ego and his short term name for himself.

title: Long term career view
pros: Over the long years of employment (30 years) I was given great opportunities to have several different careers without leaving the company. Has been a good company and full of great benefits. When I started there was a great "Weyerhaeuser Family" presence and values.
cons: Since new outside President and CEO arrived in August of 2013 the company is changing. I thought he would be a good influence and bring the company separate business on a standard approach going forward, however, in my opinion it has backfired and we are more separated than in the past. At present there is a lack of appreciation for long-term employees and recent layoffs tend to be people with 20 and 30+ years. Leaders that are being kept on not people oriented leaders, but systematic, results only leaders. This can work for a couple of years but after a while, with more and more employee benefits disappearing and this type of leadership, people will leave. This may result in a company that can only attract mediocre employees as high performers will be able to go elsewhere. The new president has NO value or appreciation for our rich history -- very sad as a long term employee. I have seen, participate and adjusted in the many, many changes at Weyerhaeuser, however, during all those changes an element of striving for financial success and caring for their employees has always been present. Yes, I have lost a lot of benefits I had when I first started but still supported the company as our core values were still in place, but for the first time in over 30 years, I would not recommend this company.

In past years, it's been great to work here--pay is good and I worked with an incredible group of very talented, smart and fun people.
cons: The housing crash has made this company slash jobs--which was understandable for a while. But it's been going on now for nearly 7 years! Even though the economy is now improving and profits are up, they are still looking for ways to cut, cut cut---even when the cuts don't make sense. Recent changes are really impacting customers, which will definitely hurt the company in the long run. Both customers and employees are now taking a back seat to stockholders and the bottom line. I no longer trust that the leaders of this company. Their decisions seemed very short-sighted.

title: Company operating in the past
pros: Weyerhaeuser has great people, although most of them have been with the company a minimum of 20 years. The benefits are great. They still pay a good portion of the medical plan, have a 401k match and a pension. Most organizations offer an acceptable work life balance. Safety is a value that Weyerhaeuser believes in and exhibits each day. Great job in the area. Gives you a whole new appreciation of risk.
cons: Weyerhaeuser lives in the past! The culture is slow to adapt to changing times and could be seen as reactionary. Weyerhaeuser's strategy has not been clearly articulated for years and they clearly pander to Wall Street. The environment is political with long timers having inappropriate influence. Many people have been in the same roles for 20+ years. The way things have always been influences business decisions. Nepotism runs rapid. The company has difficulty retaining new employees. Paid vacation is 2 weeks for the first 5 years.

title: A once great company destroyed by poor leadership.
pros: Great and loyal co-workers. South Puget Sound commute.
cons: Technology is treated as a necessary evil. Thus they have no clear direction for those that work in IT. Applications, infrastructure and vendors are swapped out on a monthly basis. No IT Leadership. The current business that makes the money claims the direction conch. The CIO position has been diluted to figurehead by committee position at the director level. Keep the Lights On: This company used to be known for its innovation. Technology was what set it apart from the competition. The survival mentality has brought up a generation of leadership that will not invest in people or technology. They count on the last remaining remnants of their glory days: The loyalty of their employees. Arrogance: They offer an IT salary and compensation that is equal to other Timber companies and yet they are only 20 miles away from the top IT companies in the world.

title: Toxic Environment
pros: As a whole, I do believe that Weyerhaeuser is a good company to work for. They have good benefits, regular performance reviews, and an array of opportunities. The cons of this review are specifically related to the Technology Center in Federal Way management team. The technicians I worked with were very hard workers with great communication amongst each other.
cons: Regrettably, the management team at the Technology Center in Federal Way is shameful. My management was verbally and emotionally abusive. I requested that I not have meetings with them without a witness, which they, along with HR, told me was not an option. During a meeting with HR present, I confronted management about their behaviors. They flat out denied statements they had made and referred to my recollections as absurd. This is an incredibly toxic work environment with zero happy technicians. I would not recommend working in the technology center. They have pushed several dedicated, hard working employees out of the door in recent years. These people did not quit their jobs, they quit their managers.

title: This Used to Be My Playground
pros: One of the few south-end companies. Mid-level managers are receptive to discussion and are responsive to needs.
cons: Changes in benefits - medical, pension, 401K. I can understand cutting back on these types of things as times are currently tough. It was recently announced, however, that these changes would be permanent as (if) the company starts growing again. This company has never been fiscally responsible. When the have money, they spend it stupidly and when times are tough, the workers bear the brunt of the burden to save money (i.e. layoffs, reduction in benefits, training, etc). Outsourcing - Weyco has given away their best resource; Intellectual Property. They have outsourced most of the tribal knowledge and now are left with most of the people that can't get jobs anywhere else or folks that are too new to the company to know what the culture/process. I could go on and on...but what is the point.

title: Not what it used to be
pros: If you were to ask me 5 years ago, I would have said that it was a great place to work, good benefits, good career development opportunities, great people to work for. Now, as many others have posted, it's all about the bottom line. I understand that the company is in pretty dire financial straits, but management says it supports its employees and considers employees a critical asset, but then doesn't act as such. Ever since Rogel took over the company, it's been a steady slide downhill.
cons: With the current environment, benefits aren't what they were (but are still decent I suppose), the direction of IT management is pretty frightening when speculating about succession plans, and when the company starts picking up again, there aren't going to be any knowledgeable people left to help support that growth cycle.

title: Pay is unbalanced. The more you do the smaller your pay.
pros: Fellow employees are nice. A few managers are helpful because they came from your position too. The benefits are the best I’ve had in my career also.
cons: The upper management sucks. They send out memos nearly every week or so telling us to work a random overtime shift the week of. They’re like ghosts. Show up and shake your hand to pass out hams for Christmas or have a meeting about a 1% or 2% raise every other year. I’ve been here 5 years trying to move up with no success. I’ve tried contacting management about issues at the main office in Seattle. Phone numbers on the website are disconnected and emails are never returned.

title: This place is horrible. It sucks the life out of you
pros: There aren't many. Coworkers are nice. Decent location.
cons: Management is not made up of effective leaders. You will never be promoted. Promotions are based on whether or not you will do whatever managment wants. Have to be a puppet. Underpaid for the work you do. Benefits have been cut. You don't have time to use your vacation. Management asks for input on ways to improve, then ignores suggestions choosing to go with their "better" plan. You're given constant praise until it comes time for annual reviews. To be successful, you need to say yes a lot: "Yes, I would love more work." "Yes, your idea is better than mine." "Yes, I already make too much money." Bottom line, they don't care about their employees. It's all about pleasing the shareholders.

title: Improvement
pros: Nothing is being done correctly
cons: Everything has room for improvement

title: Western Timberlands Employee
pros: Many open positions since people quit at such a high rate, which in itself is a red-flag. This place is only a great stepping stone to obtain another job.
cons: Morale is in the gutter across all employees. Management, which has been inflated with middle managers, is flaky, incompetent, and does not have your back. Your chances of advancement depend more on the color of your nose than the quality of your work. Workers who excel are pigeon-holed in their roles while inept employees are bounced upward. Developmental training is reserved for those pre-destined for advancement (see above) and as a carrot to keep disgruntled, but essential, employees from quitting. Pay increases are withheld from entry-level to first level workers despite bring promoted and having more responsibilities. Necessary business tools, such as cellphones, have been ripped away, and you must now pay for the privilege to be on call 24/7. And don't expect to get any comp time (you WILL be working well over 60 hours/week and on weekends). Also, don't expect a work/life balance: departments are ridiculously understaffed, and your manager doesn't have one, so you won't, either. HR cannot be bothered to pretend that they even care about you; at least they're honest (in a sense).

title: Rough
pros: Large company with great pay that provides job security.
cons: Over worked. Not enough help. Superintendents don’t care about your family or your life away from the mill. They will put your life in danger just so they don’t have to worry about a problem. Largest snow storm hit in 30 years. Over a foot of Ice and Snow on the roads. They shut the whole mill down except the kilns then made me drive an hour in the weather, for a week straight, just so they could catch up on inventory. Told me they would make it up to me. Not only did they never make it up to me but they put my life and my families future in danger. They also abuse their salaried employees. Give you a salary then work you 12-16 hours a day, 6-7 days a week. Most of your hourly employees will end up making as much as a supervisor with overtime.

title: Not a destination for those who aspire to be good people leaders
pros: Benefits and compensation are strong. Work life balance is generally good but varies greatly by team. Lots of opportunities to grow.
cons: Much of Sr Leadership consists of those who 1) are technical experts and 2) manage "up" very well. Ability to lead your own direct reports well is not highly valued despite any words that exist on vision statements or posters in conference rooms

title: Middle Management is clueless but Branch Manager/Regional Manager are too!
pros: Used to be a great company to work for with good benefits. Leadership was 100% invested in the employee and the company so it was a win/win for all.
cons: Over the past 5 years, some benefits (ie health care) have deteriorated. Some branches have not received raises in over 3 years. Lots of middle managers who are "yes" men to senior mgmt but to their employees they are rude, play favorites, don't totally understand their employee's work day and what is involved on a day to day work load. Favortism is out of control and people are not held accountable if they are "in good" with middle management. Everyone is not treated the same.

pros: Very limited as a woman. As a man, there are many opportunities for growth, continuing education and bonuses.
cons: There was no opportunity for growth within the company. I experienced gender bias when it came to salary, hours worked (including lunch), continuing education and role responsibility. One example: the guy who previously held my position was able to arrive in the late morning and leave at 3pm with no issues. I, on the other hand, was told to be on site at 8AM sharp until 5PM sharp. Even if leaving for lunch I was to report my time which was closely monitored. The manager I reported to directly told me I was doing great work and he didn't know how to coach me because I was doing everything right, however, the mill manager of the site I supported was uncomfortable working with a woman so I was let go; even though I demonstrated an exemplary performance record and received several accolades from upper management in corporate. I received several suggestive advances from on site management and regret not reporting it even though it made my daily tasks uncomfortable. I experienced a similar situation in corporate and the solution was for me to try to avoid the guy so I felt I was in a tough position.

title: Electrician
pros: Great pay, hours, and time off. Everyone is willing to help out with tasks and teach you new things. 401k is 50 cents to every dollar up to 6%. 2 weeks paid vacation for the first 2 years then goes up every few after that. Cant speak much for the other benefits as I do not use them. I get a lot of good experience here as far as maintenance goes.
cons: Safety is beaten into your head big time. Its an over kill some days. I get that safety is something to take seriously and a lot of folks do, but they do not have to go to the extreme like they do. I guess that's why they are one of the safest companies to work for. Also, cant borrow against your 401k with the company matching. Also, I hired in as an electrician and hardly touch wires. Its mostly millwright work, like a 90/10 percent. the vision is to make everyone a multicraft.

title: In a word, Change
pros: Employees in corporate and manufacturing are some of the brightest and dedicated people I've ever known. The people are very friendly and genuinely care about you and your safety. Pay is reasonable for some and really great for upper management with a bonus structure that really pays out well at top levels.
cons: A lot has changed at Weyerhaeuser - the size of the company has decreased significantly and promises to get even smaller as it unloads the CF business. The location of the corporate HQ is physically moving to Seattle from Federal Way and the culture has been in a constant state of flux for years. I guess none of these things in and of themselves are bad and some of the changes may end up being really great for the company. But the impact of constant change has been challenging and it seems like people are exhausted trying to keep up with all of it.

title: A once great ship, captained by greed, headed no where, with huge iceberg in future.
pros: Always liked the people I worked with. Weyerhaeuser seems to attract good folks that were usually easy to get along with. Compensation was pretty good, as were benefits. Very relaxed work schedule. Treated the community respectfully and has always been helpful when bad things happened (i.e. natural disasters, family crisis, etc.).
cons: Slow moving. Prefers process to getting work done. Complete disconnect between corporate services and the businesses they support. Company mantra is "Shareholder Value" which gets to be pretty lame when you realize that that really means " do whatever Wall Street says." HR departments that could care less about employees and serve as clubs for management. Promotions are political, not based on merit.

title: A mixed bag in Oregon
pros: A genuine and sincere focus on safety, which I laud, but..........Compensation is slightly above average, and health insurance is ok. Workload is reasonably to easy.
cons: Very slow to react, with the exception to safety. If safety were a salable commodity we'd have the corner, block, and city on the market, but its not. Don't misunderstand, I have worked elsewhere, to others safety is a word given lip service, here it is the real thing. Some things, however, need to be dealt with common sense. A lot of talent and experience is wasted because of ineptitude, ego, and territorialism by middle management. Meetings, and the voluminous amount of Emails don't help me do my job; a Manager and Planning Dept. that are there to support me would. Work Orders that tell me my housekeeping responsibilities, or the need to review upcoming jobs for parts etc waste your time and don't benefit me. In general, a lot of missed opportunity.

title: Excellent company who's current executive leadership stinks
pros: I worked at the corporate headquarters for over 16 years. The team that I worked on was excellent. My immediate leadership was responsive, flexible and supportive. Weyerhaeuser allows immediate leadership quite a lot of autonomy. While this can make for tremendous differences from business function to business function, it empowers leaders to support their employees as the employees support the businesses. I also have the opportunity to have several varied and different jobs/careers during my time there. If you are someone who likes to make career changes and seek new challenges, there are opportunities to do so.
cons: In 2016, the company moved their Corporate Headquarters to the armpit of downtown Seattle, known as Pioneer Square. The commute combined with the location (we were told it's a neighborhood in "transition") makes working for the corporate region of Weyerhaeuser less than a one-star rating for this review.

title: Where have all the intelligent people gone............???????
pros: Co-workers behaved toward and cared about each other as in a closely knit family.
cons: Chauvenism is alive and well within the "Good Ole Boys" club at the top. No chance for women to advance except for the token few and the men aren't even afraid to say so to their faces! It's sad that the only veteran management employees left are the ones that were paid the least to begin with and really have no clue about which way to turn when they get to a new crossroad. Ethics Committee and Human Resources are in place to help management only. Do not contact them if you need the information to be kept confidential or are looking for resolution involving conflict with management.

title: Soul-sucking environment at HQ
pros: -Good people in the trenches and in the field -Pretty new building in Seattle (but see cons) -People pull their weight -Good advancement opportunities if you are willing to relocate
cons: -Below average pay and bennies for Seattle -Pioneer Square has gotten awful over the last 3 years. More the City's fault than W's, but employees are stuck with it. -Cube world and tight quarters are soul-sucking. Employees (well, not senior management, naturally) are stacked on top of each other. Privacy and ability to talk on the phone are non-existent. -Only when you leave do you realize how caustic the environment is. It's like you've been holding your breathe and you can finally exhale. -Plum Creek people did not integrate well. -Stock price has been in the dumps. Is this the market's vote on management?

title: Overall a good company
pros: Company has a rich history and a great culture. Company is very ethical and employee safety is placed above everything, including profit. Company has a culture that most people will enjoy and produces something of value to society by engaging in sustainable foresty and taking care of the environment.
cons: Limited opportunity in the present environment given the economy, significant losses and job reductions. Not sure if senior management is really focused on employee satisfaction. Seems employees are a liability rather than an asset like they were viewed prior to the current CEO. Also not sure what the long-term strategy is.

pros: The people are great. I like everyone I work with, from managers on down. The tools I'm given to work with are excellent.
cons: I'm one of many Weyerhaeuser employees looking at the unemployment line before the end of the year. What was a happy place to work just a couple of years ago is bleeding money and trying to stay alive, and they're doing it by starving some IT services and doing as little as possible to keep others alive. And all the while, critical IT services are outsourced instead of being fufilled by highly capable local employees.

title: Its not the same Weyerhaeuser we all knew :(
pros: Interesting and varied work with highly talented co-workers. Flexible work schedule. Beautiful setting in the woods. Great short term profit sharing.
cons: New CEO has quickly changed the R&D culture from innovation to bean counting. Short term view makes me question the long term existence of R&D. Corp is moving to Seattle, divorcing any connection with the existing community. Middle management has difficulty in planning and communicating the future. Specific business focus means no one has an eye on "outside the box" opportunities that cross business lines. What used to be a culture of constantly developing innovative products has digressing into the maintenance of commodity products. Good for short term, not so much for long term . . .

title: Opportunity Lost
pros: Flexible work schedule Decent benefits Promotes volunteerism
cons: Promotions are made through favoritism, chauvinism, and cronyism. The path to success - do not challenge existing ideas, processes, or implementation; be cunning and manipulative; accept only unaccountable responsibilities. Upper management views IT/software as a production line, rather than an innovative and creative process. Best practices are discouraged if they will extend an estimated work effort. Technical decisions are dictated by product management and business stakeholders rather than those with the technical expertise. Poor internal practices are reinforced by weak product management and a mandate by upper management that projects are released to both scope and date. Quality and usability are not a priority.

title: Exciting jobs in a misguided company
pros: Lots of fun and challenging things to work on with the possibility to work at many different locations throughout the country. Lots of people have worked here for many years and have valuable information that can be learned that may not be known anywhere else. With so many older workers the potential for younger employees should be great as a large number of the working population of Weyerhaeuser will be approaching retirement age soon. This will leave a large void that will need to be filled be younger employees.
cons: Limited communication and direction from senior management as to the path of the company and how an employee can assist in moving the company down that path.

title: No longer a good place to work
pros: They paid pretty well and I liked my co-workers.
cons: They are no longer the company they once were. They claim to care about employees (using their "safety culture" as evidence) but really they only care about shareholders and the bottom line. They've have no consideration for their employees demonstrated by the fact that when the Boise location closed and they offered many employees relocation to Federal Way, they didn't bother to mention that the Corporate office would relocate to Seattle by 2016. Now all those relocated employees who bought homes south of Federal Way are stuck with a 2-hour+ commute to Seattle in heavy traffic. Thanks so much. Your ethics really stink.

title: Growth - up to a point
pros: Pay was good compared to other companies in the area. Benefits were pretty good too. In most of my jobs here I was allowed a lot of autonomy and flexibility as long as I performed. There was a focus on development and promotion, but only up to a certain point. Once you hit your perceived performance high, you were on your own for career progression.
cons: Cultures are totally inconsistent between departments so it is hard to succeed in a different environment. It is really hard to transfer between businesses or support functions - you get pigeonholed into a segment.

title: If you can wait it out
pros: Company currently has a reasonable benefit package, although that is changing. Pay scale is adequate but not strongly competitive. However, because the company is struggling through a prolonged downturn, there should be opportunities if you are still employed "when the market turns around".
cons: The company made a commitment to "all things residential construction", and are vertically integrated (timberlands, building materials manufacturing, building materials distribution, residential real estate) with few options except residential construction. With the current economic situation, there is not much the rest of the company (not dependent on housing) can do to hold up the weight of businesses that can't make money until residential construction becomes profitable. Just when you think they can't cut anything else . . . they do.

title: Run away as fast as you can
pros: - Subsidized transit - Vacation/sick time - Benefits ok but are cut every year - 401K match - Pay is ok for Federal Way not for Seattle
cons: - Moving to Pioneer Square which is a dangerous place to be even in broad daylight - limited flexibility and teleworking even with the huge increase in commute times - Constantly cutting staff - No real vision for the future except to cut manufacturing - CEO is a one-trick pony and weak leader - Women are not valued and are limited in what positions they are considered for - Benefits being cut every year with no real explanation

title: Good culture
pros: Best company I have worked at yet. The people that I work with make the experience great. It is a very dynamic work environment and I have learned a lot by being here
cons: There are many people here that are so used to doing things "the way we have always done them" that they miss out on opportunities to do things better. Having an outside approach and various experiences normally has been a benefit to the work environment.

title: Former Fortune 500 Good Ol' Boys Club
pros: The benefits used to be some of the absolute best in the nation.
cons: After the Insiders Club comprised of the Board of Directors announced their "New Vision" for the company a few years ago, they all dumped millions of dollars of their own shares the following day, knowing they would be doing so since they had to file SEC documentation the week prior to doing so, sending the stock into a downward spiral from which it would never recover, leaving the rest of our retirement we'd spent years building to dwindle to nothing. They preach a safety and diversity culture while skirting around and covering for the people in management positions who fail to make the grade.

title: WY is flushing out experienced older works
pros: Bringing in new MBA's that lack work experience but are quick to learn
cons: Pushing out those with experience to lead, guide and train the new hires. There is no sense of comradery, no feeling that the top executives all the way down to the managers care about the employees. The company is still laying folks off, so you come in every day and never know if you will have a job. This has been going on for years.

title: What worked 100 years ago, won't work today...
pros: Weyerhaeuser pays well. In small parts of the company, there is freedom to build a culture of mutual respect, empowered teams and personal development.
cons: There are only a few small parts of the company where you can affect the culture - the rest blows by you with their "100 year old company - good ole boys club" mentality and curbs enthusiasm for change that is desperately needed. The company seems to make poor decisions about what to keep and what to sell/divest. They sell businesses that make them money and keep the ones that are dragging them down. Communication is sub-par. Employees hear about what's happening at the same time the public hears about it.

title: Ethical Company - Proud to be Here
pros: Great culture of integrity, diversity and respect for others. Absolutely amazing safety focus and this company means it. Increasingly focused on high performance and winning at everything it does.
cons: The near constant sell off of business units and corporate downsizing within Weyerhaeuser over the last 10 years has left an indelible mark. The challenge for Weyerhaeuser is to remake itself into a growth company and a destination that more prospective employees will seek out. The company faces stiff challenges to achieve this due to its REIT corporate structure which places limits on re-investment in non-REIT business units where most of the people work e.g. manufacturing.

title: Tough times, but hang in there!
pros: They work hard to keep talent...no matter what others say, they treat their top performers well. I've been there for five years and my father has worked there for 30 years and through all the restructuring and downsizing and "right-sizing" we've been through, we've learned that if you stick it out and are fortunate to have a job when it's all over, it really is a better company to work for in the end.
cons: They're going through some long over-due changes right now and it's a little scary, but it's for the best. The main downside from a personal view for me is that they do not at this time allow tele-commuting which would be nice, but it's not a deal breaker!!

title: Overall a good company with a mid-20th century management style
pros: Good salary and benefits Good co-workers - competent Work is interesting and rewarding Many resources available to get job done Millions and millions of trees -- the foundation of this company
cons: Culture of company took 180 deg change about 10 years ago after merger with another forest products company. Once people were respected and their ideas appreciated. Now the company is run with a top-down, command and control management style (popular in the mid-20th century). Threats, authority and fault-finding are key tools used in this style of management.

title: Sales
pros: There really isn't anything positive left in the distribution side of the business. They still however are a powerhouse in the timberlands and manufacturing.
cons: Management is completely incompetent, and has no real understanding of how to take product to market. They are also unaware of how little market share they really have, and they still try to make decisions like they are market leaders that can drive change. Customers and employees alike have a lot of unanswered questions on the future plans for the some businesses under the Weyco umbrella, and it makes it very difficult to put any kind of program business in place. Replenishment is trying to be done from a far with little or no understanding of local markets. In a nutshell, it's a big mess.

title: Great work environment
pros: Focus on production goes hand-in-hand with support to all personnel. The quality of work is based on the quality of workers and they use local people in their facilities to support the community and ensure the workers have a vested interest in both the community and the company.
cons: Very few - harsh conditions due to the facility being a large plant that makes a product requiring heat and loud equipment. However, all necessary actions are taken to make employees as comfortable as possible to prevent heat stress and hyperthermia!

title: Weyerhaeuser IT
pros: It's hard to find a pro, the best that I could think of is that they seem to be semi flexible about working from home when you need to.
cons: Possibly the most disorganized and chaotic IT environment I have ever seen. Weyerhaeuser has a long history of selling off bits of the company and downsizing staff at the same time which sets the mood there. Contractors do all the real work and they choose the cheapest contractors they can find, and you get what you pay for. There are three separate silo'ed IT departments that do not work together well and duplicate or contradictory projects may be going on at the same time.

title: Time for a change.
pros: Very safe workplace! Industry leader, innovator, global name recognition. Vast potential in it's resources.
cons: Use to be fair and equitable treatment company to work for, no longer. Too much emphasis on soft skills and not about getting the work done better and providing excellant customer service. To munch politicing, advancement based on "diversity" instead of merit. Give better direction and communication on where the company is headed over the next few years. Actions speak louder then words, value people for their contributions, not for their socializing abilities. Teamwork is not something you learn in a book but something you attain through life experiences

title: Provided a decent range of opportunities and experiences
pros: Large company with very deep roots in the integrated wood products industry. They are process driven and provide for good understanding in their development. Safety is of HUGE importance at Weyerhaeuser. You can count on a safe working environment.
cons: Leadership structure is very hierarchical - a bit old school. If you are a person who is looking to work for a value added company, this really isn't the place as they are highly commodity oriented. Safety culture nearly consumes the purpose for the existence of the company - to make money.

title: Co, Execs & Mgmt THINK they are GREAT. BUT! - they don't listen, make stupid moves, no initiative
pros: they pay well. total comp pkg was pretty good - salary, insurance, decent bonus, 401-k + 50% match
cons: HA! where to begin?!? staffing # are up & down like a yoyo. mgt says "we can't predict what the needs will be." right. eliminating jobs in one area only to add in another. they call it "right sizing". others call it bs. other co.'s staff at a level where they don't have to "eliminate jobs". apparently some over-hire and have to compensate when mkt changes

title: Good Place to Work
pros: I have worked for Weyerhaeuser for 15+ years in various businesses, multiple sites/states and multiple jobs (hourly production to management.) In my experience, Weyerhaeusr is committed to ensuring a safe working environment, following strong environmental practices, maintaining great business ethics, encouraging strong community involvement, and providing competitive wages and benefits. The people I have worked with in this time care about one another, appreciate our diversity and creativitiy, are passionate about what they do and accept nothing less than the best.
cons: Our culture seems to have changed from feeling like a small, family-like organization to a profit driven business.

title: OK but not as good as it used to be
pros: Solid Benefits and decent pay
cons: Poor communication from management Poor leadership If you want growth be prepared to move where ever in the US they want you to go (unless you get lucky and can move up where you are)

title: Good at the Mill level, not sure where Corporate is going.
pros: Good people to work with Local Management is trying hard to make it a safe and enjoyable place to work
cons: Corporate leadership has taken questionable steps: -Sold off or shut down large portions of the company. -Implemented Salary/Wage freeze, Suspended 401K match, Suspended Bonus program, but senior leadership still received stock grants. -Tranistioning to reduced medical & retirement benefits in 2010 - placing more burden on the employee.

title: Weyerhaeuser, great legacy with no future
pros: There used to be many more reasons but unfortunately leadership has destroyed a company 100 years in the making in just a few years time. The best asset was the competence and dedication of the worker bees and they have either been divested or left on their own accord to go to other organizations with competent leadership and a future.
cons: Poor leadership pimping the integrity and future of the company for short term stock holders gain and actually failed at that ultimately as well.

title: Would not recommend
pros: Working in the Seattle HQ is a big step up from the dinosaur buildings in Federal Way. Management seems to think that employees place a financial value on the work environment though and we are told that our work environment is 25% of our compensation. It's a beautiful but soul-less building in a neighborhood where you will be assaulted if you're a female in a skirt and heels. Shouldn't be a problem though since most likely if you work here you are white and male.
cons: The resounding chorus heard throughout the low-cubicles on all seven floors: I have too much work to do, I can't keep up! To tolerate the high demands of work here you have to be able to truly leave your work when you leave the building. I always felt like I was failing (despite positive annual reviews) and when I told my manager he said he understood, that he also felt overloaded, but that we had to just persevere. The culture as a result is one of complaints and negativity, and my more talented colleagues in Seattle have ended up moving on to other opportunities. Regarding compensation, they seem to offer mid to low end of the salary range and have been transparent about their desire to attract mid to low end in terms of talent.

title: In 10 years I have seen a great workplace to become horrible. Never thought Weyerhaeuser would be one of those places.
pros: none anymore. It has been a great company, before they started their secret agenda of selling off the company. At least Senior Management is getting a deal out of it.
cons: The company will pretty much disappear in the next couple of years. Next, iLevel will be sold, and at the end the company is going to be back to where it was 104 years ago, growing trees and that's it.

title: Good HR policies and practices
pros: Like the culture, people and short commute. Love my job supporting SAP. Believe in the mission and goals of the company and am very impressed with emphasis on safety for all workers, employees and contractors.
cons: Not a technology company and does not adopt new technology trends as quickly. It is mainly detrimental to my type of career as I don't get to use the latest operating system (Windows XP on my desktop) or new apps as quickly as I'd like to. Leadership mentoring and career advancements are not plentiful.

title: Great company being too strongly influenced by investors
pros: Great benefits package and competitive wages. If you are fortunate to have a great manager, you have a good chance of attaining a good work life balance.
cons: The company runs very lean, so the amount of work employees are expected to complete is not realistic in a standard works schedule. On the flip side of my positive comment. If you don't have a manager that is understanding, your work life balance will really suffer. The company has not come out with a top down policy to make it equitable. The company is also making many decisions based on investor feedback.

title: Production team member
pros: Good Company to work for, you are always busy. A lot of very nice people in the company. Enjoy my job working outside and inside.
cons: Not a whole lot of upward movement in my area, job progression is at a stand still. A lot of you haven't been here long enough to get that promotion even though I have showed the competency. Not a whole lot of onboard training to new employees.

title: What is Weyerhaeuser's direction?
pros: Trying to compensate for the Seattle location by incorporating fun events. There has been a slight change in the culture since moving to Seattle in order to stay relevant and try to be competitive with Seattle companies.
cons: Pay and vacation are NOT competitive in the Seattle market. We now have no fitness benefits and this has brought down morale with many in the organization.

title: Weyerhauser in tough times
pros: In the past there have been a lot of opportunities for new and different challenges. The real forest land assets owned by the company gives me hope for the future as the building market increases. More opportunities will be there for those that survive the tough economic times.
cons: Severe reductions in the work force in the supporting organizations has created a very negative working environment. The cuts have come wave after wave leaving those that survive a feeling of continued uncertainty.

title: OK overall, stale and political leadership, lots of lifers
pros: Very focused on safety of employees. Individual teams tend to work very well together and be loyal. Very little advancement during the downturn, but a good incentive program if you are high enough up in the company.
cons: Very political leadership team. Lots of egos and power plays. They talk a lot about growth and advancement but more words than actions. Lots of meetings that are a waste of time because the decisions are actually made with the cronies in the hallway.

title: It's good.
pros: Management does respect the employees. We get time off with no problem, and they treat everyone fairly. Also the pay is good for this area.
cons: The heat has to be the worst part of my job. The work can be labor intensive sometimes, but we get breaks often.

title: Until I was laid off I had a very good experience.
pros: The company was flexible on schedule. I could come and go as I pleased and take days off pretty much whenever. I liked the independence.
cons: The company was not managed well and when the economy tanked there were so many people that lost their jobs. I think they could have handled it better had they been more fiscally responsible.

title: Great culture, but not competitive
pros: Great team environment, good work /life balance, opportunities to get onto separate projects or other teams, strong focus on developing people, encouraged to improve processes
cons: Pay and benefits are not competitive for Seattle, management slow on communicating changes, not flexible when it comes to working from home, lacking in diversity, favoritism comes into play a lot for manager decisions, managers do not always act on employee concerns

title: A company that struggles to pass the torch to the next generation.
pros: The benefits are great. Management was always considerate of work-life balance.
cons: Weyerhaeuser struggles with developing new talent. Risk aversion is a common theme throughout the corporate office, and they want to feel 100% confident that you will be able to perform new tasks. Basically, if you are a young and ambitious individual; this isn't the place for you. This ultimately leads to missed opportunities with newer employees, and continues place a heavier burden on a lot of the aging staff, that have been there for many years, to complete what needs to be done.

title: New CEO is changing the culture
pros: Compensation, benefits, Federal Way, WA location are attractive features.
cons: Leadership is changing the culture and not for the good. Management is distrusted and there is skepticism over their real motives for moving the headquarters to Seattle. If you value job security, Weyerhaeuser is not the place to be employed. Downsizing and sell off of assets are constants at Weyerhaeuser.

title: Old school company trying to modernize
pros: Majority of people want to do the right thing. People generally treat each other with respect.
cons: Business practices are behind the times. They were trying to catch up, but the severe downturn in housing starts caused massive layoffs and process improvement is suffering. Businesses (wood products, real estate, and cellulose fibers) are tied too much to housing, and their large holdings of timberlands will probably be spun off into a REIT. Will not be a good place to work for a few more years.

title: The company has changed a lot since 2008 and not all of the change is good.
pros: Solid benefits package Excellent pay Great coworkers Bonus pay when operational criteria are met. Best in industry products and services
cons: Limited advancement unless you’re in sales Too dependent on metrics and documentation for reviews. Has gone from being employee driven to very top down.

title: Best place I have ever worked.
pros: They are very big on safety. What I have learned, I have taken with me. Pay is good, as well as benefits. Very good people to work with, while I was there.
cons: Long hours if you work shift, but well worth it with the time off. Very difficult to come back there, even if you leave on good terms and excellent work record, after 9 years with them.

title: Top heavy
pros: Decent benefits, you get some good experience if you are the right "kind" of person. Some good people to work with.
cons: Constantly taking something away from the production associates. Management tells you they want your opinion, but you quickly find out if it's not in line with theirs they pick you out, then shut you out, then find a reason to get you out. Too many cons to list.

title: On the cusp...
pros: Many good people (may have to search to find them), some decent management (newer) who want to steer the company in a more efficient direction. The desire for positive change is present.
cons: Entrenched employees are very resistant to any sort of change/improvement to processes. 5 separate IT departments interrupt efficiency. Instead of acting like an IT department in a Fortune 500 company, the approach is much more mom and pop.

title: He got what he came for, but he's leaving us with nothing.
pros: I have experienced managers who are very caring about your life outside of work. I have been here for 2 decades and have worked part time for a few years, and flex time for the last six. The employee community in general gets involved in many volunteer activites, and always gets engaged when some world crisis occurs. I was really proud of the outpouring of dollars after Katrina. Both from the company and from individuals. Weyerhaeuser also sponsored employees to go to the affected area for 2-3 weeks at a time to help rebuild. That says something about the company to me.
cons: Although the company is in the process of getting smaller, in my time with the company it has always been a "big" company - with big company bureaucracy. This makes everything slow and complicated. I often felt that lip service was paid to being fast, simple and decisive. Part of our management behaviors regarded being courageous. We saw first hand with our director that challenging the status quo or rocking the boat was not rewarded. As with any company, big or small, your experience is dependent on your direct manager. I've had great ones, and I've had really awful, toxic ones. Weyerhaeuser was very slow to act in getting rid of the bad leaders - but in my case they finally did.

title: A company in change
pros: The people were great. Management does care about people but it was hard to see at the cuts have to take place. But that is business.
cons: Very silo approach for much of the work and therefore they are missing out on some great opportunities. It was hard to leave but the company has gone through major changes. It will not be the same company as it was years ago.

title: Caring about people and creating better communities
pros: Weyerhaeuser leads by example from the leadership on down. The company is the leader in Forestry practices and follows that up by action. In creating wood products Weyerhaeuser makes to give back to the communities it works in by giving grants to local causes. The pay and benefits are better than average. There is also many opportunities to grow into a new position.
cons: Commute into Seattle office can be long for some( although wfh opportunities are growing for certain positions)

title: Look at the long term, don't give up the assets now that will give you that competitave advantage 5, 10 years from now.
pros: It's a company that has been around for over 100 years with it has a proud tradition.
cons: It is a slow campany in terms of reacting to the market. It is a the mercy of Wall Street.

title: Great fun while it lasted
pros: I worked with great people, both in the corporate region and in the mills. The company name was well respected. And the value placed on safety - going home as healthy as you arrived at work - is top tier for any industry. I had great opportunities to learn and at times to have a real impact, but...
cons: New CEO ( 8/2013) is (IMHO) working for the shareholders near term cashout, not the long term success of the company or long term investors. Corporate overhead is being slashed, and the individual businesses are being siloed from each other. Expertise and experience gained over decades is being riffed out, retiring, or leaving voluntarily.. Weyerhaeuser has been divesting big chunks of itself over the last decade, and the siloing of the remaining businesses makes that process even easier. I wouldn't bank on there being anything left in the portfolio except Timberlands 3-5 years from now. And the current corp. campus in Federal Way is on the market, and corporate functions are moving to Pioneer Square - not sure that one corp office is enough to make Pioneer Square an appealing place to work. And it puts pretty much everyone into the horrible Seattle commute. Fed Way was a "reverse" commute for Seattle-ites and not bad for folks coming from the south and east.

title: The Sheer Arrogance of Management - No women in engineering
pros: Better than no paycheck at all
cons: Engineering Planner when asked about difficulty operators face using LOTOT system using numbers rather that common names "because we have to order the stuff". Women are not able to do the jobs they used to. Jobs that used to be routinely held by women are now far to difficult (heavy lifting, awkward lifting, zero attempt to rectify the situation). There have never been many, but now there are no (zero) women in engineering.

title: Weyerhaeuser: it's about trees.
pros: Weyerhaeuser employees have great technical expertise. In my experience, many leaders in the company do actually care about both employees and the company.
cons: There is a serious lack of upward mobility. Although former CEO S.Rogel is no longer with the company, Weyerhaeuser will be years if not decades recovering from some of the extremely poor decisions he lead.

title: OK place to work before the downsizing
pros: When it was a large company there were opportunities to move between businesses to expand your knowledge of the company and build skills in other systems. Benefits and pay were good.
cons: Lack of true leadership of the company. CEO at that time did not relate well to senior management team or employees. People were not recognized as assets of the company.

title: This company had done a complete 180 since I started. Used to be a fun happy place to work ot anymore
pros: The coworkers are by far the reason of pros. It used to be pay but what's expected for the pay isn't worth it.
cons: Management! Morale is at a all time low. Not appreciated. Work your days off. Words actually cant explain what this place has become.

title: The Good, The Bad and the Ugly!
pros: The employees and work environment are pleasant. Campus is beautiful and availability to health and recreation possibilities are good.
cons: Still feel as though it is more of a "Good 'Ol Boys" environment. Positions are not always awarded to the most qualified, but the most well liked. There have been some strides made, but it is still a lumbering (sorry for the pun) large business in forward thinking. Feel they will sell you a bogus bill of goods to get your cooperation only to renig on "promises" made for the future.

title: Good company that is trying to make forest products a sexy and exciting business.
pros: Culture and values. Great, sincere and hard working employees, ability to move around, reasonable pay, real pension plan. There is a diverse set of business allowing folks to find a niche area that interests them.
cons: Culture change, frequent cuts to save costs, elimination of traditional perk programs such as workout rooms, limited sense of job security in new company.

title: Depends on what you can do
pros: Hours. You put in so many hours it makes the pay amazing. Vacation is used by the hour not the week. Insurance and benefits are good. A company very well connected to other companies. Allowing for discounts on hotels, cellphone bills, etc
cons: You will not have a life. 12 hr shifts rotating. Some areas are forced to work all holidays and weekends. Your nose and mouth will be filled with black soot. Dust and dirt EVERYWHERE. They only do promotions based on seniority. Regardless of work ethic. Your length of time there determines who moves up the ladder first.

title: Building materials LEADER in the industry!
pros: -Historically & presently a real LEADER in the building materials industry. -Environmental concerns are taken seriously. Forests are managed seriously and with much thought for both products and communities. -Competitors tend to sell for less but no one compares to Weyerhaeuser's service levels. -Different opportunities are abundant if you are willing to relocate, as there are many locations throughout the United States all within many different divisions.
cons: -The execution and follow through after adopting new technologies and processes, leaves something to be desired. -The building materials industry as a whole is very late to the DE&I conversations.

title: Low stress job; good pay for effort.
pros: Work was relatively easy and low stress I rarely had to work overtime and never had a problem taking off when I wanted to The people were great to work with and we hung out outside of work They have a great internship program, which I started with I like their recognition and rewards system that they use to give you positive feedback
cons: Lack of opportunity for advancement Salary was much less than I could get elsewhere (albeit more hours/expectations) Management was not good at mentoring

title: Excellent times in 80's - 90's going downhill from 2002 onward, spiralling down fast after 2008
pros: Depends on what decade you refer to, used to be the people and the managers were great. It was always pro-people and one felt valued. Classic Weyerhaeuser managers focused on keeping the clutter that trickled down from on high from interfering with our work and production. All one had to do was the job. Period. I am lucky to have had a long career with a great company in the good times. And to have finally escaped the banality of what it sadly became. Job rating 1978-2007 = 9/10. Rating 2007-2011 = 1/10. Huge difference. Had a great time mostly, not bitter, not sad, just kind of a shame of what has befallen perhaps.
cons: In the last 3-4 years it all went badly at R&D, primarily due to almost cartoonishly bad onsite management. Hard to know what happened, or who is to blame, but basically during SG&A reductions, many good people were targeted for layoff programs, but their managers always survived and got 'reassigned'. The place became a circus tent of way too many average-at-best managers, with nothing to do but annoy, pester and make life difficult and do so on a daily basis. Someone had decided that they needed to become more hands-on I suppose. By late 2008 an inane fascination with process and safety had overidden any focus on production. One had to work hard to just keep busy. So called improvements on safety and the RIR after 2008 has been a disorganized 3 ring circus, truly absurd to see it happen. I finally learned what the old saying 'inmates running the asylum' means. Painfull.

title: Decent compensation, propaganda machine with toxic culture
pros: Plenty of work to be done, never boring Decent benefits & compensation
cons: No accountability to help get the work done, they will work you to death with no support Toxic culture fostered by middle management, favoritism Most of the good talent has left - supposed campaign to improve retention announced a year or two ago has done nothing (propaganda)

title: Manager
pros: Very fair compensation, medical, dental, 401k benefits. Probably leads most of the industry
cons: Constant organizational and leadership changes in the last few years have caused significant decline in morale. Focus is on cost reduction at any cost to please the shareholder

title: Culture is changing which is good
pros: Starting with the CEO and then the move to Seattle, the culture is changing in a good way. The company is starting to recognize the need and advantage of getting up to speed on technology improvements across the business.
cons: Still long way to go in terms of technology. For instance there is no CRM. For a corporation of this size, and with the amount of revenue it is always a surprise for someone to hear that.

title: lot more changes needing to take place
pros: currently benefits and field personnel are dedicated to work hard
cons: now a smaller company that hasn't transitioned to smaller company nimble thinking. management talks of appreciation but there are no individual pats on the back. recently, many lower management types got their salary grades reduced and were eliminated from any long term incentive plans

title: Spec Pro, I don't think so...
pros: The pay is okay and no one is held accountable for anything. This makes for an environment where opportunities won't present themselves, but if you don't mind just putting in 40 hours a week and not having to think about work when you are at home, it is not that bad.
cons: Zero opportunity for advancement due to the small nature of the company.

title: Poor management with a gloomy future
pros: Great environment, nice office with 30 year old water fountains. Benefits are still decent (while having it). company matching our 401k
cons: constantly making empty promises. extremely unfair to minorities. full of office politics. lack of communication and commitment. extremely poor morale in every division

title: Research Technician III
pros: peers were dedicated and helpful, project was interesting and challenging, medical benefits were decent, lab equipment was fairly up to date and engineering for up and coming changes was encouraging
cons: management cultured an environment that was bias and toxic, funding support from company was focused on meeting unattainable costs when compared to an inferior product, no room for growth

title: Dank
pros: Develop and breed trees to make the best paper using tech on cutting edge. Few things other than the projects results are what is considered when performance is reviewed. Value of your project is based solely on core tangibles like monetary impact, potential high profile coverage.
cons: Many hoops to jump through before you can put your idea into prototype. Teams are always being pushed as a suggested option but lately the hiring process has been including team setting behavior and observing interactions within the department to basically clique up the new guys.

title: Employee
pros: Above market salaries & benefits, interesting and challenging work. Not too political or bureaucratic and employees are generally empowered and engaged. Would have worked there for the foreseeable future if the merger with WY had not occurred.
cons: Work environment (office in Columbia Falls MT) is sub-standard. Since there is a 20 word minimum requirement, I will go on to say that this was a great place to work before the merger with WY.

title: Macro economic and industry structural changes with unclear impact to all in company.
pros: - Generally relaxed, well- balanced, polite organization. No attitude - easy. - Corporate campus setting is beautiful.
cons: - Forest Products Industry declining fast, company reorganizing to survive. Employment is not stable, near term. - Strong culture and established network of long-term employees, difficult for new hires to rise make impact quickly. Not for ambitious person.

title: Growth Opportunity
pros: -Wonderful people who care about your well-being -Relaxed environment -Huge opportunity to learn about the industry. You will be surrounded with people who are are at the top of their field and they are overall happy to teach.
cons: - Filled with 'yes men' who seem to not want to make waves by addressing the issues. -Changing business model. Becoming more corporate with every passing year. No one/no sector of the business is considered sacred or safe from the chopping block. -HQ just moved to Seattle. That commute is pure unadulterated misery.

title: Come Here to Learn, Not for the Pay
pros: - A variety of learning opportunities make this a great place to work. - For a timber/real estate company, the emphasis on technology and the cloud is impressive. - Work-life balance is a good perk.
cons: - Underwhelming compensation makes this company less attractive in comparison to software engineering companies in the Seattle area. - Employee progression to the next level can feel slow.

title: Would I recommned them YES, would I go return, I don't think so
pros: Prof Growth Opps Generally Hire very good "line-level" associates Benefits and work environment are very good Safety is highest priority, even in the office environment
cons: In a cyclical industry, so layoffs are not uncommon Not always looking for long term value in software development Don't really understand how software development needs to work, still treat it like building they are building a widget.

title: Layoffs and Job Eliminations an Annual Thing
pros: Trees really are the answer and Weyerhaeuser plants a lot of them. A robust research program means that Weyerhaeuser could reemerge as an industry leader.
cons: Weyerhaeuser is in a massive contraction mode and has been for several years. Singular focus is on cutting costs. Morale is very low as repeated layoffs have gutted teams. Senior management is out of touch or simply does not care about employees.

title: Gained more knowledge of what high safety standards really means.
pros: I know I would be great at this job because I've done everything they describe in their requirements for so many years.
cons: Probably just getting acclimated to a new environment.

title: I've been with the company for more than 10 years
pros: It ia a good company to work for good pay and great benefit s. I enjoy working there.
cons: As in any job there's good and bad. It gets hot in the summer and cold in the winter,all of this is explained before you arè hired

title: Excellent Company Culture
pros: The company culture and people at Weyerhaeuser is the #1 reason to work here. This is reflected by the number of individuals who work 30, 35, 40, and 45+ years with the company. Weyerhaeuser truly cares about their employees as well as the communities they operate by providing resources, grants and donations to local organizations including allowing employees to participate during business hours. I would highly recommend Weyerhaeuser.
cons: There could be additional full-time employee positions added in areas where workload is high.

title: Administrative Secretary
pros: Lots of good people work at Weyerhaeuser, but it is definitely an older workforce. They are an interesting place to learn tons of things.
cons: Instability of jobs at Weyerhaeuser, some managers that shouldn't be managers, negative atmosphere. New CEO appears to carry only about stock holders, no longer are the employees the #1 asset!

title: Good Place to Work - Definately not perfect
pros: Most people are very good to work with.
cons: Constant churning of whether we are growing, shrinking, centralizing, de-centralizing by upper management is just plain tiring. For employees that have been here for awhile, they just roll their eyes. Each change is just what previous senior manager tried before - its just another turn of the wheel. Hopefully, this current SMT will stay focused on their current approach.

title: Weyerhaeuser opportunites
pros: well compensated with salaries and benefits when compared to other industries and manufacturing in general still have pension plans available interesting market challenges to focus on for growth potential
cons: questionable future of this type of industry and manufacutring in general unclear path forward for entry level or mid career employees with downsizing over the past few years, not as many opportunities company wide for growth

title: Very nice people with very low turnover.
pros: Everyone that works at corporate HQ is very nice. There are lots people who have been working there for 20+ years. I work with someone who has been there over 30 years. So many old timers mean they value their employees. They also still have a pension plan!
cons: I have not experienced any yet. However I have not been there long.

title: Worst
pros: None not a single reason to have anything good
cons: Poor conditions. Unsafe, bad managers, poor maintenance. Watch managers steal gas from the Company gas pumps and use in their personal autos. Managers take afternoons off to go golfing and claim meeting time. Use company credit cards and turn in as meeting expense. Yeah I am pretty sour on them but dang staling everywhere and the mistreat the employees trying to get the job done...its really wild. I am glad I am out that place, I was really shocked at all tha went on. No wonder they had a big downsize in 2011.

title: Great employer
pros: Weyerhaeuser treated employees ethically and with respect. The small companies I worked for after leaving due to corporate downsizing were not at all comparable and the difference was palpable. Weyerhaeuser trained and empowered employees. We were given proper tools and training to do our jobs. We were kept informed and not treated like wayward children.
cons: It was difficult to be promoted when budgets were crunched and managers withheld long promised promotions to stay under budget.

title: Great Company
pros: Salaried Employees, great pay, great benefits, great company all together. Great people, great location, great working hours and it was a pleasure to work in teams.
cons: At will company which means they have the right to fire you with or without cause. Working outside can be rough at times.

title: Shift Team Leader (Product Line)
pros: Compensation good, solid learning structure, possibility for advancement
cons: Upper management tends to micromanage, top heavy management, too many salary positions looking to validate their value. Front line management not allowed freedom to manage area without constant input and negative feedback from superiors.

title: Great people to work with
pros: Weyerhaeuser deeply cares about each employee returning home safely. Every leader is helpful and nice to work with. There is a good balance between home and work life. Sometimes days can be long, but it is part of the job. The benefits are fantastic. Plenty of opportunities to grow and move up within the company.
cons: The only con I have is how dirty it can get here. Housekeeping is an issue.

title: ITS REALLY GOOD IF YOUR A GUY.
pros: The pay is good and there are alot of "perks". Having one week off per month is great and the vacation time (length)is fair, for length of service.
cons: They are chauvinistic towards women. Had problems with this the entire time. Working twelve hour swing shift is very hard on kids and family life.

title: Overall a good place to work, but lots of changes.
pros: Highly ethical leadership. Lots of lifers and loyalty and people who come here to stay. Decent opportunities for promotion or moving around internally.
cons: Change was very slow. Benefits cut. Downsizing was hard. Salaries could be better. There were a couple of people that were tough to work for or with, but not a lot of jerks. Work/life balance was pretty good.

title: It's not for everyone
pros: Four days off every week Pay competitive for the area Work is not extremely hard We work four days on, four days off, so when you take vacation, you get 12 days off for every four day rotation you take off
cons: Long hours, swing shifts expect to work weekends, holidays etc The work is indoor/outdoor combo so, it's hot in the summer (100+ degrees in some places,) and cold in the winter

title: A great, caring company
pros: A very strong, caring culture with the highest safety commitment of any organization. Employees build lasting, long term relationships and chose to stay with the company for a long time. Most employees have at least 15 years of service. Very strong work ethic, dedicated, smart employees who give back to their communities. .
cons: The forest products industry is very cyclical so it can be tough to ride the commodity markets....highly dependent on housing.

title: Production Planning
pros: I really enjoyed the years at Weyerhaeuser. I was allowed to experience many different positions to gain an all encompassing understanding of the shipping container industry. The disciplines included accounting, production management, and sales. They even paid for my MBA. Additionally, an understanding of the benefits of managing a union shop has been very valuable.
cons: Oh dear God, the hours 80-90 per week, somewhat like Amazon. This left little balance in my personal life, which was destroyed.

title: Meh.
pros: The new location in Pioneer Square is terrific. For the wrong reasons (saving money) they are willing to push people fast and high.
cons: WY's employee philosophy is to hit just below the 50% mark in every conceivable way. Pay slightly less, have slightly sub-par benefits, and value employees only to the extent you can get a lot out of them for little investment.

title: Good people but long hours
pros: Relaxed group of great people who come together to support each other when needed
cons: Management doesn't seem to work toward the corporate visions well if they even pay it any attention. Also as a salaried employee long hours are expected with no real compensation. The union is king and gets away with to much leaving the salaried team to get blamed.

title: Good while it lasted
pros: Small Office part of a large company. Work-life balance is good. Software work is interesting - the engineering that goes into houses.
cons: Tied to the housing industry. Half the staff got laid off at once. No room for personal growth, promotions. Culture is not as good as it used to be...

title: Long-term employee
pros: Great people to work with. Good values. Good compensation. Flexible work environment.
cons: Another round of downsizing coming from the new CEO. The morale was just starting to improve. 2008-2012 was like going through a war. Just when we thought it was over, we have to worry if the next bomb is going to come down on us.

title: My experience at weyerhaeuser was the very worst i've ever been a part of.
pros: The best is the work experience, then dealing with people in general, after that it's learning exactly who you are. They'll push you.
cons: The downside is that if you get hurt on the job and it's due to mechanical malfunction, THEY WILL TRY AND FORCE YOU OUT, BECAUSE FOR SOME PEOPLE THEY DON'T HAVE LIGHT DUTY. FRONT OFFICE BREAKS ALL THE RULES

title: My experiene has been accademically fulfilling with great variety in the work I do.
pros: Wonderful people, great safety culture, everyone cares about each other and it's a beautiful place to work.
cons: Like any corporation they are beholden to their shareholdes and as a result I have been through many rounds of layoffs. It is stressfull when it happens and hard to see your coworkers leave. Afterward it can be difficult to pick up the slack but you do.

title: Environmental Manager
pros: Good team to work with that are committed to success. Company rewards good performance at all levels of the organization.
cons: Similar to other large companies benefits have been significantly reduced over the last few years, such as having to use your personal cell phone for work.

title: Intriguing
pros: Gave me a fantastic experience to learn and grow as and engineering student. I would say that they are very understanding of how college affects work and the other way round
cons: The lack of ability to move around with in the company as a co-op, I am unsure if this is true for all co-ops though

title: Stores Purchasing Manager
pros: Efficient, on time, quick learner, always perform above expectations.
cons: When asked to complete other non departmental projects & If I absolutely can not, Its EXTREMELY hard for me to reject this. I always want to help EVERYONE.

title: Decent company
pros: Pros are highly dependent on where you work within the company. Culture changes by division and location. People, including leadership, are hard workers and care about their people.
cons: My biggest complaint has always been work-life balance. Expected to work weekends and holidays. In manufacturing, I am not sure how you could change that.

title: Okay.
pros: We receive fair pay, relative to other companies. This company is socially responsible, as there's focus on our community and a healthy environment.
cons: The near term outlook is relatively dim, considering our industry (wood products, housing) and the poor market associated with it.

title: Retirement & Insurance

title: Keep looking forward for the economy to turn around. This is a great company to work for.
pros: Weyerhaeuser is a company that doesn't just talk the talk. They actually uphold the values they claim. When they say employee safety is the top priority they really mean it. Safety is actually a metric that has direct monitary impact on compensation from the executive management all the way down to the front line. This is also the reason that for 2008 they actually achieved a less than 1.0 recordable incident rate, and this is for a forestry company with loggers and mill workers. I think this is a testament to the leadership. 2007 and 2008 have been extraordinarily difficult times for the company financially. A great deal of extremely talented folks were let go. I can't say this for all of the areas in the company but I know that I felt like I was always in the loop with were we were and the reality of a layoff months before it actually happened. The strong ethical approach the leadership displayed really helped to emotionally deal with such a large layoff of some of the world's best talent in the industry. When things turn around for the economy, I have no doubt that this same leadership style will continue. There is a reason the company has been around for 109 years and a Fortune 100 company.
cons: Not really enough vacation time compared to other companies. The rest of the benefits are great though.

title: Highly competent employees and good worklife balance
pros: Excellent work life balance with onsite fitness center, reasonable flexibility in work hours, occasional telecommuting (great remote access tools). Most employees/contractors are very competent...especially after the major downsizing in 2009 due to the recession. Lots of interest in sustainability, biofuels and other innovations relative to using trees (WY is certified in sustainable forestry and treats and cares for its timberlands as vital, renewable assets).
cons: Still a big company so still a lot of politics, and managers enjoy and favor their sycophants. Mixed bag on pay, they compare themselves nationally for IT salaries despite the fact there is high demand for IT, and higher salaries, a few miles north in Seattle. Company was well positioned to catch the full force of the recession: 3 of the 4 major company divisions are tied to housing (Real Estate, Building Materials, and Timberlands), so it is still reeling. Significant recovery with current business mix will lag the rest of the economy by 12-18 months so Co is hunkered down. New innovations are probably years away from market.
